direction.raw_text: S the green, squared-off flatland, lit only by a fine sunset in its final throes. Then, gradually, starting from nothing, a rumble is heard, quickly growing louder and louder until the sound of a train can be recognized.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S quickly, discovering the railroad line atop a man-made rise of land, and the speeding passenger train is upon us, flashing by with a roar. Then, as if from nowhere, the figure of a man hits the embankment and rolls crazily down to the bottom into the thick underbrush alongside the tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- BODY It lies in the bushes, still, unmoving -- dead. CAMERA PANS AWAY to the quiet peaceful countryside as the sound of the train fades off until there is silence once more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: begins with a crash. (MAIN TITLES)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MEGEVE -- DAY A handsome and elegant hotel perched on the mountain-side overlooking the French resort town. A large, open sun deck -- tables, gaily colored parasols, sun bathers. One of the latter is REGINA LAMPERT, a lovely young girl. She is, besides taking in the sun, involved in her favorite activity -- eating. Then -- a dark, ominous shape intrudes in the f.g. FOCUS CHANGES to bring into sharp relief a revolver -- shining, black and ugly in the sunlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: unaware of her danger, continues to eat. The finger tightens around the trigger and finally the gun shoots -- a stream of water arcs, with unerring aim, straight into REGGIE's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Including JEAN-LOUIS, a French boy of six or so. REGGIE looks at him sternly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in for trouble) Oh, la.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell me you didn't know it was loaded. (calling) Sylvie!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE SYLVIE GAUDET, French, attractive, blonde, in her early thirties, comes from the railing of the sun deck to join REGGIE and JEAN-LOUIS.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Isn't there something constructive he can do -- like start an avalanche?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to JEAN-LOUIS) Va jouer, mon ange.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: scampers off, content to have gotten off so lightly. SYLVIE notices REGGIE's lunch which consists of cold chicken, potato salad, rolls and butter, wine and coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer from REGGIE. SYLVIE begins reading a magazine as REGGIE continues eating.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When you start to eat like this something is the matter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sylvie -- I'm getting a divorce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ca alors! From Charles?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's the only husband I've got. I tried to make it work, I really have -- but -- SYLVIE But what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know how to explain it. I'm just too miserable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: picks up a chicken leg and starts off. SYLVIE regards the devastated table before following.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It is infuriating that your unhappiness does not turn to fat!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . SWIMMING POOL -- DAY A magnificent indoor, glass-enclosed pool, the vista of snow- covered mountains seen through the ceiling-high windows beyond. REGGIE and SYLVIE are passing through, their conversation continuing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: But why do you want a divorce?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because I don't love him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that is no reason to get a divorce!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL TERRACE -- DAY An open balcony running around two sides of the pool, sun- worshippers lying in deck-chairs. REGGIE and SYLVIE appear, their conversation continuing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stops as she is aware of a weird figure hovering over her. She wheels, terrified.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: With a rich husband and this year's clothes you will not find it difficult to make some new friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sitting) I admit I moved to Paris because I was tired of American Provincial, but that doesn't mean I'm ready for French Traditional. I loathe the idea of divorce, Sylvie, but -- if only Charles had been honest with me -- that's all I ask of anybody -- the simple truth. But with him, everything is secrecy and lies. He's hiding something -- something frightening -- something terrible -- and evil.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- PERUVIAN SNOW-MASK A strange, grotesque knitted mask that completely covers the face except for eyes, nose and mouth. The eyes inside this particular mask stare down at REGGIE.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Does this belong to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S down to include JEAN-LOUIS, his hand held firmly by the man in the mask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE Including REGGIE, MAN, SYLVIE and JEAN-LOUIS. REGGIE is too terrified to answer. Realizing this, the man, PETER JOSHUA, takes off the snow-mask to reveal a handsome, tanned face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eyeing one, then the other, SYLVIE sizes up the situation and rises.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, forgive me. (indicating JEAN-LOUIS) Is this yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (indicating SYLVIE) It's hers. Where'd you find him, robbing a bank?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was throwing snowballs at Baron Rothschild. (a pause) We don't know each other, do we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why, do you think we're going to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know -- how would I know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid I already know a great many people. Until one of them dies I couldn't possibly meet anyone else.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Yes, of course. But you will let me know if anyone goes on the critical list (he starts off)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quitter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning) How's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You give up awfully easy, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Viens, Jean-Louis, let us take a walk. I have never seen a Rothschild before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and JEAN-LOUIS start off, but not before the boy squirts PETER with his pistol.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (drying) Clever fellow -- almost missed me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid you're blocking my view.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (moving) Sorry. Which view would you like?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The one you're blocking. This is the last chance I have -- I'm flying back to Paris this afternoon. What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Peter Joshua.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm Regina Lampert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there a Mr. Lampert?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, it isn't. I'm getting a divorce.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, not on my account.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, you see, I don't really love him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, you're honest, anyway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I am -- I'm compulsive about it -- dishonesty infuriates me. Like when you go into a drugstore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure I -- REGGIE Well, you go in and you ask for some toothpaste -- the small size -- and the man brings you the large size. You tell him you wanted the small size but he says the large size is the small size. I always thought the large size was the largest size, but he says that the family size, the economy size and the giant size are all larger than the large size -- that the large size is the smallest size there is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there a Mrs. Joshua?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but we're divorced.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That wasn't a proposal -- I was just curious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is your husband with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Charles is hardly ever with me. First it was separate rooms -- now we're trying it with cities. What do people call you -- Pete?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Joshua. (turning to go) Well, I've enjoyed talking with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now you're angry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I'm not -- I've got some packing to do. I'm also going back to Paris today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Well, wasn't it Shakespeare who said: "When strangers do meet they should erelong see one another again"?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shakespeare never said that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's terrible -- you just made it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the idea's right, anyway. Are you going to call me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you in the book?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charles is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is there only one Charles Lampert?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE Her face clouding.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lord, I hope so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

result.ToD: AVENUE FOCH -- LAMPERT APARTMENT HOUSE -- DAY
result.heading: AVENUE FOCH -- LAMPERT APARTMENT HOUSE -- DAY

direction.raw_text: . AVENUE FOCH -- LAMPERT APARTMENT HOUSE -- DAY The Arc de Triomphe at the far end of the Avenue. CAMERA PANS to pick up a TAXI as it pulls up before the handsome building. Inside are REGGIE, SYLVIE and JEAN-LOUIS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- TAXI -- LAMPERT APARTMENT HOUSE As REGGIE climbs out and the DRIVER begins unloading her suitcases.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goodbye, Sylvie, and thanks. (She turns toward the house)
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sticks his head out of the taxi window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When you get your divorce will you be going back to America?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- THE TAXI REGGIE looks at SYLVIE, surprised.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He knows everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to JEAN-LOUIS) Don't you want me to stay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, of course -- but if you went back and wrote me a letter -- REGGIE -- you could have the stamps. I'll get you some here, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: walks toward the house with the driver, who carries her cases.  She presses the button that electrically opens the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . APARTMENT LANDING -- DAY As the elevator rises REGGIE gets out, followed by the driver. He puts down the bags in front of the apartment door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The driver leaves. She goes to the door and presses the minuterie, the button that turns on the time-light, and the lights come on. Then she rings the doorbell. There is no answer. She rings again. Still nothing. Sighing, she digs out her keys and starts to fit it into the lock. At this moment the minuterie expires, plunging the scene into darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She finds the button and the light goes on again. She inserts the key and turns it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (handing him a tip) Merci.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wonderful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LAMPERT APARTMENT -- ENTRANCE HALL -- DAY CLOSE SHOT -- DOOR as it opens and REGGIE steps into the CLOSE SHOT. She stops, her expression changing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From REGGIE's p.o.v. as CAMERA PANS the entrance hall. It is bare -- no furniture, no rug, no pictures, no nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE She stares for a moment, then goes back out into the landing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . APARTMENT LANDING -- DAY As REGGIE steps back outside. She looks at the nameplate beside the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: NAMEPLATE It reads "MR. AND MRS. CHARLES LAMPERT."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks at the plate in disbelief, then turns and hurries back into the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . LAMPERT APARTMENT -- DAY As REGGIE hurries into the entrance hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No answer. Now, CAMERA FOLLOWING, she goes into the Salon. It is also empty -- stripped bare. There are squares of the wall's original color where paintings used to hang, the hooks still in the wall. She rushes now, going into the bedroom, CAMERA FOLLOWING crazily, lurching and careening behind her. The bedroom, too, is empty. She goes to the built-in wardrobe closets and throws open all the doors. Only some hangers remain. She pulls open the drawers -- nothing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns, and running now, goes through another door to the library, CAMERA FOLLOWING. The rows of shelves are as empty as the rest of the apartment. She begins to turn in a circle, looking for something, anything. In a panic she turns and runs out, colliding suddenly with a MAN whom she (and we) have not noticed until the moment of impact.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Honorine -- !
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charles -- !
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: screams.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- INSPECTOR GRANDPIERRE A heavy-set man of no particular age with tobacco-colored hair, and thick glasses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Madame Charles Lampert?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE Including REGGIE, in a state of near-shock.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am Inspector Edouard Grandpierre of the Police Judiciaire. Would you be so kind as to come with me, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MORGUE -- DAY We see a large metal drawer being opened and an all-too- familiar shape outlined under a damp sheet of muslin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- OVERHEAD Looking straight down at the tops of REGGIE's, GRANDPIERRE's and an ATTENDANT's head and smack into the open drawer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: lifts a corner of the sheet at the bottom and reveals a bare foot with a ticket tied to its big toe. He stoops to read it. Satisfied, he recovers the foot, then moves to the other end to uncover the head.  As the sheet starts to lift:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: REGGIE as she looks down into the CAMERA. She closes her eyes for a moment, then looks again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods again. GRANDPIERRE moves into the SHOT.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Well, Madame -- ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You are positive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You loved him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm very cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: nods as he turns to the unseen ATTENDANT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: suddenly moves as the 'drawer' is slid back into the wall. BLACKNESS comes with a loud clang and continues while the echo dies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . GRANDPIERRE'S OFFICE -- DAY CLOSE SHOT -- DESK DRAWER (FROM ABOVE) as it is pulled open. A photograph of Charles Lampert lies face up in the drawer. A hand reaches in and pulls it out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE Including GRANDPIERRE sitting behind his desk, and REGGIE, sitting across from him. The office is as bare as most policemen's offices. GRANDPIERRE studies the photo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She starts to rummage through her bag. GRANDPIERRE shoves a package of French cigarettes across the desk to her. But she pulls a package of nuts out of her bag. She begins separating the shells with her thumb nail and eating the nuts, depositing the shells in the ashtray. GRANDPIERRE watches this for an instant.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We discovered your husband's body lying next to the tracks of the Paris- Bourdeaux railroad line. He was dressed only in his pajamas. Do you know of any reason why he might have wished to leave France?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your husband possessed a ticket of passage on the 'Maranguape.' It sailed from Bordeaux for Maracaibo this morning at seven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (a pause) I'm very confused.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was American?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Swiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Swiss. His profession?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He didn't have one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was a wealthy man?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. I suppose so.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: About how wealthy would you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where did he keep his money?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Besides yourself, who is his nearest relation?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (exploding) C'est absurde, Madame. To-tale-ment absurde!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know. (pause) I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sighs, puts down his pencil and pushes a button on the desk. He removes a cigar from his desk and inserts it into his mouth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He rips the cigar out of his mouth and slams it back into the drawer, closing it fiercely. A UNIFORMED POLICEMAN sticks his head in the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The POLICEMAN leaves and closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He opens the desk drawer, puts the cigar back in his mouth and lights a match by scratching it against the glass desk- top before he remembers REGGIE's request. He puts it back in the drawer again. The door opens and the POLICEMAN enters again, this time carrying a wicker basket which he deposits on GRANDPIERRE's desk, and leaves. GRANDPIERRE peers into the basket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He begins to take them out, placing them on the desk, identifying each item as he does.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is it all right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish you wouldn't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Les effets de Lampert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On Wednesday last your husband sold the entire contents of the apartment at public auction. Furniture, clothing, kitchenware -- everything. The gallery, in complying with his wishes, paid him in cash. One million two hundred and fifty thousand New Francs. In dollars, a quarter of a million. The authorities in Bordeaux have searched his compartment on the train. They have searched it thoroughly. They did not find $250,000, Madame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: These few things are all that was found in the train compartment. There was no other baggage. Your husband must have been in a great hurry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One wallet containing four thousand francs -- one agenda -- (pausing, he opens the notebook)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: his last notation was made yesterday -- Thursday -- (reading) "Five p.m. -- Jardin des Champs- Elysees" (looking up) Why there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Perhaps he met somebody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (dryly) Obviously. (returning to the items in the basket) One ticket of passage to South America -- one letter, stamped but unsealed, addressed to you -- REGGIE (lighting up) A letter? May I see it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: hands her the letter and watches her closely as she reads it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He slides a sheet of paper and pen across to her, then starts to put the things back into the basket while he speaks:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches into the desk drawer and pulls out a passport which he hands to her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (reading) "My dear Regina: I hope you are enjoying your holiday. Megeve can be so lovely this time of year. The days pass very slowly and I hope to see you soon. As always, Charles. P.S. Your dentist called yesterday. Your appointment has been changed." (she looks up, puzzled) Not very much, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We took the liberty of calling your dentist -- we thought, perhaps, we would learn something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Your appointment has been changed. (he smiles at his little joke, then returns to the basket) One key to your apartment -- one comb -- one fountain pen --  one toothbrush -- one tin of tooth powder (he looks up)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: that is all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you will sign this list you may take the things with you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (sighing) Is that all? Can I go now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: One more question. Is this your husband's passport?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- PASSPORT The cover indicates that it is Swiss. REGGIE's hand opens it to a picture of a man -- the man we saw in GRANDPIERRE's photo. Under it is the name: "CHARLES LAMPERT."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND GRANDPIERRE REGGIE Of course it is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands her another passport.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- SECOND PASSPORT The cover is American. When it is opened, we see the identical picture, but the name under it reads: "CHARLES VOSS."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND GRANDPIERRE REGGIE I don't understand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands her, one at a time, two more passports.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: And this? And this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- THIRD AND FOURTH PASSPORTS One is Italian which, when opened, shows the same photo with the name "CARLO FABRI." The other is Venezuelan, the same photo, and the name "CARLOS MORENO."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND GRANDPIERRE GRANDPIERRE Have you nothing to say, Madame?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: looks down at the four passports, then back to GRANDPIERRE.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hopefully) It's all right if you want to smoke your cigar now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . LAMPERT APARTMENT -- DUSK The house is empty as before. Now it is silent, the late afternoon light coming from outside. REGGIE stands by a window. A canvas airline bag rests on the floor nearby. Suddenly there is the noise of a DOOR OPENING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE As her head turns, in alarm, toward the noise. There is a moment of silence, then FOOTSTEPS are heard, coming closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As PETER enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks around for the light switch, then goes to it and flicks it on -- nothing happens. He flicks it a few more times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She shakes her head. PETER looks around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods. He picks up the airlines bag and they start out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised) What are you doing here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I phoned but nobody answered. I wanted to tell you how sorry I am -- and to find out if there was anything I could do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you find out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's in all the afternoon papers. I'm very sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I rang the bell but I don't think it's working.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes it is -- I heard it this morning.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They must have turned off the electricity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where did everything go?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charles sold it all -- at auction.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know what you're going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Try and get my old job back at UNESCO, I suppose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Doing what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm a simultaneous translator -- like Sylvie, only she's English to French -- I'm French to English. That's what I did before I married Charles. The police probably think I killed him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Instant divorce you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something like that. But I'm sorry it ended like this -- tossed off a train like a sack of third-class mail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (Taking her hand) Come on. You can't stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know where to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We'll find you a hotel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not too expensive -- I'm not a lady of leisure anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Something modest but clean -- and near enough to UNESCO so you can take a cab when it rains -- okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: stops at the door and looks back.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I loved this room -- but Charles never saw it -- only what was in it. All those exquisite things -- (looking around) I think I prefer it like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL CHAPEL -- DAY CLOSE SHOT of a phonograph. A hand appears, starts the record on it spinning, then places the arm at the beginning. An instant later ORGAN MUSIC starts with a roar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . FUNERAL CHAPEL -- DAY CLOSE SHOT of the coffin. It rests on a low platform, with a bouquet or two of flowers near the head, the lid open. Inside, the face made up to look lifelike (but failing), lie the remnants of Charles Lampert.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- GRANDPIERRE The INSPECTOR sits quietly, eyes downcast, staring at his hands in a prayer-like attitude. CAMERA PULLS BACK, revealing row after row of empty wooden bench-like seats in the large, dimly-lit, high-ceilinged room. Finally, in the first row, REGGIE and SYLVIE are discovered. Besides GRANDPIERRE, they are the only ones present. REGGIE turns around to look at the empty room. They speak in whispers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's not exactly what I'd call a large turn-out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't Charles have any friends?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't ask me -- I'm only the widow. (indicating GRANDPIERRE) If Charles had died in bed we wouldn't even have him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least he knows how to behave at funerals.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- GRANDPIERRE His eyes still lowered. CAMERA PANS DOWN to feature his hands -- he is methodically trimming his nails with a small clipper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- SYLVIE AND REGGIE SYLVIE Have you no idea who could have done it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The front DOOR of the Chapel is heard opening and a shaft of daylight streams in. The WOMEN turn.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Until two days ago all I really knew about Charles was his name -- now it turns out I didn't even know that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- CHAPEL DOOR The short, heavy-set figure of a MAN is outlined against the bright outdoor light. He stands for a moment, then closes the door after him. LEOPOLD GIDEON, short-sighted, bald, in his middle forties, glances around nervously, like a barnyard bird. Then he walks down one of the side aisles of the Chapel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- GRANDPIERRE As he watches GIDEON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE As she watches him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- THE BIER GIDEON arrives at the coffin. He stops, looks down at LAMPERT's body for a moment. Then, suddenly, in rapid succession, he sneezes six times. He takes a small bottle from his pocket, shakes a pill from it and swallows it dry. He turns and walks back up the aisle, looking for a place to sit. He comes face to face with GRANDPIERRE, stops, turns to sit somewhere else.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND SYLVIE SYLVIE Do you know him?
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've never seen him before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He must have known Charles pretty well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can you tell?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's allergic to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: turns and glances at GIDEON. Again, the sound of the DOOR opening interrupts them. They turn to look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- CHAPEL DOOR Again the figure of a MAN is outlined in silhouette against the outside brightness. When he closes the door we can see "TEX" PENTHOLLOW, a slim, rangy man with sandy-colored hair, a weatherbeaten face, washed-out blue-eyes -- also in his forties. He wears a velvet-corduroy suit, string tie and a bright yellow flower in his lapel. A bulldurham tag hangs from his outside breast pocket, dangling from its string. He starts down the aisle toward the bier, CAMERA LEADING him, and we notice his unsteady gait. He turns to look at the others present.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- TEX'S P.O.V. MOVING down the aisle. GRANDPIERRE's face, then GIDEON's, then REGGIE's and SYLVIE's -- all staring at CAMERA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- THE BIER As TEX arrives. He stands staring at LAMPERT's body, swaying on his feet until he reaches out and grabs the side of the coffin to steady himself. Then he takes the flower from his lapel and throws it into the open box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- TEX TEX (heavy Texas accent) Ariva durchy, Charlie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: R ANGLE As TEX turns away from the coffin and approaches REGGIE and SYLVIE, addressing the latter -- after having first reached for his hat which he discovers he isn't wearing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miz Lampert, ma'am...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: points to REGGIE. Unruffled, TEX starts over. addressing REGGIE this time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But TEX has nodded his head and moved off to find a seat. When he spots GIDEON, the two men stare at each other. Finally, TEX chooses a seat away from him and sits.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Miz Lampert, ma'am...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Charlie had no call to handling it this-a-way. He sure didn't. No siree.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understa--
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- CHAPEL DOOR It flies open, this time with a bang, and the large MAN who appears almost fills the frame.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- TEX As the loud noise awakens him with a snort, mid-snore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- THE DOOR Closing the door, we see HERMAN SCOBIE, a heavy-weight -- tall and wide, but not fat -- with black hair combed straight back and heavy bushy eyebrows of a matching color, which meet over his nose and join up. About the same age as the first two men, SCOBIE is dressed in a battered raincoat, his hands thrust deep in the pockets. He marches down the aisle. Looking straight ahead, CAMERA PANNING with him. He stops before the coffin and stares into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- SCOBIE As he stares down into the coffin, his tongue trying to dislodge a bit of food caught in his teeth. He stares hard at the body, squinting his eyes. Then he removes one hand from his pocket, removes a pin from the inside of his lapel, picks his teeth with it, then slowly lets the hand down, into the coffin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- SCOBIE'S HAND The pin held between thumb and forefinger, he jabs it slowly but positively deep into the back of one of the dead man's hands. There is no reaction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- SCOBIE He watches the dead man carefully, still squinting. Then finally satisfied, he returns the pin to his lapel and walks back up the aisle and out of the door, slamming it after him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE Having watched SCOBIE exit. Suddenly a hand falls on her shoulder. She jumps in alarm and utters a little cry of fright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Featuring a funeral ATTENDANT, a cadaverous type (aren't they all) with a black cut-away coat and an over-solicitous, unctuous manner. He is eternally bent at the waist, in a sort of half bow. He offers REGGIE a letter which she takes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He backs off and is gone. REGGIE looks at the letter, back and front, then starts to open it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She pulls out the letter and starts to read it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Merci, Monsieur.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pas du tout, madame, pardon -- pardon -- pardon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who is it from?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The American Embassy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- THE LETTER It bears the Great Seal as a letterhead and the typed message reads: "Dear Mrs. Lampert: Please drop by my office tomorrow at noon-thirty. I am anxious to discuss the matter of your late husband's death. Sincerely, (signed) H. Bartholomew."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND SYLVIE SYLVIE has been reading over REGGIE's shoulder.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know.  But if this is a sample of American diplomacy I'm buying a fallout shelter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . THE AMERICAN EMBASSY -- ESTABLISHING -- DAY The fine old building in the Rue Gabriel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EMBASSY CORRIDOR -- DAY As REGGIE leaves the elevator two young DIPLOMATIC TYPES step in, immersed in conversation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The elevator door closes on them. REGGIE reacts to this and starts down the hall, finally stopping at the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I bluffed the Old Man out of the last pot -- with a pair of deuces.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's so depressing about that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If I can do it, what are the Russians doing to him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- DOOR It is marked "307-A  H. BARTHOLOMEW." REGGIE checks the letter, then opens the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BARTHOLOMEW'S OUTER OFFICE -- DAY The office is empty, the typewriter on the secretary's desk is covered with its plastic shroud. REGGIE enters, looks for somebody, notices that the door to the private office is slightly ajar.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (tentatively) Hello -- ? (there is no answer) Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) (from the private office) Is there anything wrong, Miss Tompkins?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh -- Miss Tompkins isn't here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: comes to the door and looks in. He is a pale grey-haired man who looks, on first examination, older than his forty-odd years. Sickly would be the word that describes him best -- pallid, consumptive-looking. He wears heavy tortoise-framed glasses which fall down his nose and cause him to push them back in place every so often with a quick automatic motion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He motions for her to enter, standing aside to let her do so.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry -- my secretary must have gone to lunch. You are -- ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mrs. Lampert -- Mrs. Charles Lampert.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking at his watch) Come in, Mrs. Lampert. You're quite late.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BARTHOLOMEW'S PRIVATE OFFICE -- DAY A small cubicle -- there is a silver-framed photo of three kids on the desk. BARTHOLOMEW indicates a chair, then goes behind his desk and sits. A can of lighter fluid stands open on the desk and a crumpled hankie beside it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He works at a stain on his necktie with lighter fluid and hankie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks up at her, laughs silently, then goes back to his tie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts away the lighter fluid in a desk drawer, smells the hankie, passes on it, then sticks it in his pocket. He opens another drawer and pulls out various sandwiches wrapped in waxpaper, a salt and pepper shaker, a tube of mustard, a bottle of red wine and two Dixie cups.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He uncorks the wine, fills a cup and begins eating.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hands her a sandwich and fills a wine-cup for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reaches back into the drawer and pulls out a glass which he gives her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me for a moment, Mrs. Lampert -- it's a stubborn little devil.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dry-cleaningwise, things are all fouled up. I had a good man -- an excellent man on the Rue Ponthieu, but H.Q. asked us to use the plant here in the building -- to ease the gold outflow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bartholomew -- are you sure you know who I am?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (looking up) Charles Lampert's widow -- yes? (going back to the tie) Last time I sent out a tie only the spot came back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Voila! As they say.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have some, please. I've got... (checking) ...liverwurst -- liverwurst -- chicken and -- liverwurst.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No thanks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know what C.I.A. is, Mrs. Lampert?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't suppose it's an airline, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Central Intelligence Agency -- C.I.A.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean spies and things like that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only we call them agents.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We? You mean you're --?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someone has to do it, Mrs. Lampert -- REGGIE I'm sorry, it's just that I didn't think that you people were supposed to admit -- BARTHOLOMEW I'm not an agent, Mrs. Lampert -- I'm an administrator -- a desk jockey -- trying to run a bureau of overworked men with under-allocated funds. Congress seems to think that all a spy needs -- REGGIE Agent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- That all he needs is a code book and a cyanide pill and he's in business.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's all this got to do with me, Mr. Bartholomew?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (his mouth full) Your husband was wanted by the U. S. government.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: May I have a sandwich, please?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To be more specific, he was wanted by this agency.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (eating) So that was it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. We knew him, of course, by his real name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (almost choking) His -- real -- ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Voss -- Charles Voss. All right, Mrs. Voss -- (taking a photo from his desk)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'd like you to look at this photograph, please -- by the way, you saw this one, didn't you? (indicating the kids on the desk) Scott, Cathy, and Ham, Jr.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very sweet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't they?  Now look at this one, Mrs. Voss, and -- REGGIE Stop calling me that! Lampert's the name on the marriage license.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes -- and tell me if you recognize anyone. Just a moment. Have a good look.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- PHOTO FOUR MEN, all in army uniform, sitting behind a table. The glass is held over the first, magnifying the face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- PHOTO It's a photo of a young CHARLES LAMPERT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The glass and CAMERA move to the next man -- a young TEX.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The glass and CAMERA move to the third face -- a young GIDEON.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The glass and CAMERA move to the fourth face -- a young SCOBIE.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's Charles!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Very good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) He looks so young -- when was this taken?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . The next face, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) It's the man who came to the funeral yesterday -- I'm sure of it -- a tall man in a corduroy suit and string tie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Does the name Tex Penthollow mean anything to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Next, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yes -- and he was there, too -- a little fatter now -- and less hair -- but it's the same one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Do you know him, Mrs. Vo -- Mrs. Lampert? Leopold W. Gideon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) The last one, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) That's a face you don't forget -- he was there too -- BARTHOLOMEW'S VOICE (O.S.) Herman Scobie. And you've never seen him before, either?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) No, thank heaven.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND BARTHOLOMEW BARTHOLOMEW (a pause, regarding her) Mrs. Lampert, I'm afraid you're in a great deal of danger.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Danger? Why should I be in any danger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're Charles Voss's wife -- now that he's dead you're their only lead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bartholomew -- if you're trying to frighten me you're doing a really first-rate job! (she takes another sandwich)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, do what we ask, Mrs. Lampert -- it's your only chance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gladly, only I don't know what you want! You haven't told me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, haven't I? The money -- Mrs. Lampert -- the money. The $250,000 Charles Voss received from the auction. Those three men want it, too -- they want it very badly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But it's Charles's money, not theirs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Oh, Mrs. Lampert! I'd love to see you try and convince them of that! (drying his eyes) Oh, dear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then whose is it? His or theirs?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (she looks at him for a moment) Oh, I see.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And I'm afraid we want it back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I don't have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's impossible. You're the only one who could have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry it's impossible. It's the truth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is silent for a moment, thinking.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I believe you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks very much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, you've got the money all right -- you just don't know you've got it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Bartholomew -- if I had a quarter of a million dollars, believe me, I'd know it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nevertheless, Mrs Lampert -- you've got it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean it's just lying around someplace -- all that cash?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or a safe deposit key, a certified check, a baggage claim -- you look for it, Mrs. Lampert -- I'm quite sure you'll find it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But -- BARTHOLOMEW Look for it, Mrs. Lampert -- look just as hard and as fast as you can. You may not have a great deal of time. Those men know you have it just as surely as we do. You won't be safe until the money's in our hands. Is that clear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: nods. He writes something on a pad of paper and tears it off, handing it to her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here's where you're to call me -- day or night. It's a direct line to both my office and my apartment. Don't lose it, Mrs. Lampert -- and please don't tell anyone about coming to see me. It could prove fatal for them as well as yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait a minute -- you think those three men killed Charles, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've no proof, of course, but we rather think so, yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, there you are! Charles had the money with him -- so whoever killed him has it -- they have it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (grimly) Because they're still here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Like I said, Mrs Lampert -- I'm afraid you're in a great deal of danger. Remember what happened to Charles.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: takes the last sandwich and begins eating furiously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ESPLANADE DES CHAMPS-ELYEES -- DAY MED. SHOT -- GUIGNOL. One of the French Punch and Judy shows set up on certain days in the small park alongside the broad avenue between the Rond Point and the Place de la Concorde. At the moment, Judy, as always, is beating Punch with a bat. The sound of CHILDREN laughing and screaming can be heard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S -- THE CHILDREN Sitting on small benches lined up to face the stage. Their attention is fixed on the show, their belief totally suspended by the play as only children's can be -- laughing at the slapstick, booing the villain, frightened by the perils.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE Sitting on the last bench, next to some CHILDREN. They are laughing but she isn't -- she just watches, her attention caught up but her face void of emotion. The bench is too low for her, forcing her knees up almost under her chin. After a moment, PETER comes up behind her and, stepping over the benches, sits beside her. She doesn't seem to notice. [Throughout the following scene the CHILDREN and the ACTORS can be heard in the b.g.]
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns and looks at him for a moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Reggie -- ?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (vaguely) Hallo, Peter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You telephoned me to meet you. I've been standing on the corner back there -- waiting for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry -- I heard the children laughing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: from the CHILDREN. REGGIE and PETER turn toward the stage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- GUIGNOL PUNCH and JUDY are arguing loudly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND PETER PETER What's going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: CLOSE SHOT -- GUIGNOL STAGE PUNCH and JUDY are batting each other on the head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Finally, JUDY knocks Punch out of sight and a PUPPET wearing a three-cornered hat appears.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you understand French?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm still having trouble with English.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The man and the woman are married --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Yes, I can see that -- they're batting each other over the head with clubs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Who's that with the hat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- GRANDPIERRE Wearing a hat, he stands off in the background, watching.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) That's the policeman -- he wants to arrest Judy for killing Punch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- GUIGNOL STAGE JUDY and the POLICEMAN are batting one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: PUNCH's head appears on the other side of the stage, says something, then ducks out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) What's she saying now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) That she's innocent -- she didn't do it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) She did it, all right -- take it from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) I believe her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Who was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Punch, of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND PETER PETER Of course? I thought he was dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Charles was mixed up in something terrible.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He's only pretending, to teach her a lesson -- only -- (her face clouding) only he is dead, Peter -- I saw him -- he's not pretending. Somebody threw him off a train. What am I going to do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish you'd let me help you. Whatever it is, it doesn't sound like the sort of thing that a woman can handle all by herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- GUIGNOL STAGE JUDY has gotten the upper hand is now batting the POLICEMAN's brains out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- GRANDPIERRE as he winces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND PETER PETER Have you got a mirror? (she nods) Give it to me. She hands it to him and he holds it in front of her face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Right there, between your eyes -- see? Worry lines. You're much too young and too pretty to have anything like that. How about making me vice- president in charge of cheering you up?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (jumping at the suggesting) Starting tonight?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHTCLUB -- NIGHT MED. SHOT -- EMCEE. He stands on the dance floor in front of a five piece Latin dance band, a spotlight on him, wearing his professional smile as he speaks into a mike.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Bonsoir mesdames et messieurs, good evening ladies and gentlemen, guten Abend, meine Damen und Herren -- ce soir, comme tous les soirs, l'attraction ici, au Black Sheep Club, c'est vous! Venez, mesdames et messieurs, step right up, ladies and gentlemen, kommen Sie her, meine Damen en Herren, avanti, signore e signori -- avanti!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND PETER At their table. REGGIE is dressed in a lovely Givenchy dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She rises and pulls him along.

direction.raw_text: The EMCEE now circulates, forming teams, telling the patrons to line up, making sure there is a woman next to every man. REGGIE and PETER are the second couple in their line. Then the EMCEE picks up a basket of oranges and places one under the chin, held securely against the chest, of each man at the head of the line. Blowing a whistle, a signal for the game to begin and the band to play, the men turn to the women behind them and attempt to transfer the oranges from under their chins to under the chins of the women -- without using their hands. (This maneuver can only be accomplished by embracing one's partner passionately and firmly pressing the orange against the partner's throat until he or she can grip it tightly enough with the chin to turn and offer it to the person next in line, where the process begins anew. However, the slightest miscalculation, which can be brought about by any number of human frailties -- haste, modesty, inhibition or lack of co- ordination -- will surely result in losing control of the orange so that it either falls to the floor [where it can only be picked up by the chin] or it starts to roll and slide from its proper place to some other, less proper, spot on the human anatomy, forcing the man or the woman to retrieve it -- again, with the chin only. This latter is an activity which can prove extremely satisfying to old friends, or even new friends who wish to become old friends, but can only be a torment for total strangers and/or the English).
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ecoutez bien -- les regles sont tres simples -- the rules are very easy -- deux equipes -- two teams -- each with one orange -- une orange -- eine apfelsine -- un' arrancia -- held under the chin, like so -- (does it) comme ca -- and passed to the player behind you -- sans vous servir de vos mains -- using nothing but the chin -- no hands -- and keeping the orange at all costs from touching the floor. Commencez, Mesdames et Messieurs -- begin, ladies and gentlemen -- signore e signori, comminciate!

direction.raw_text: -- ORANGE GAME Some of the couples in various states of confusion, entanglement and intimacy -- all of them, naturally, hilarious.

direction.raw_text: -- PETER AND GIRL It is his turn to take the orange from a very short, but quite shapely young girl in a strapless dress (held up by an abundance of cantilever). PETER 'takes' when he sees the twin obstacles which might -- and probably will -- encumber the game but increase his worldly experience. The contest begins: because of her stature he is forced to move in low, making the ordinary embrace needed for success difficult, if not impossible. Then, inexorably, the orange starts to slip down the GIRL's front. Manfully he goes after it.

Now he turns to REGGIE and they face one another for a moment.

direction.raw_text: They go at it, working their bodies together to make it all possible. Then, for a moment, the game and the onlookers seem less important than their proximity. But, alas, they are too good despite themselves and the transfer is accomplished -- again with appreciative cheers from the TEAM.

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL CORRIDOR -- THIRD LANDING -- NIGHT As PETER (now called DYLE) leaves REGGIE's room and closes the door. He pauses for a moment, listening, hears nothing, then bends down and starts pulling at a loose thread in one of his socks. As usual, the thread unravels -- and unravels -- and unravels some more until it seems that the entire sock has come unknit. Now, taking the long thread, he bends down near the door and, taking his tie-pin, attaches one end of the thread to the bottom of REGGIE's door. He then runs the thread along the floor to his door (next door) and works it underneath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: is on the phone.

direction.raw_text: on the phone. He is silent for a moment, his face troubled.

They were, of course, your husband, Charles, the three men who showed up at his funeral yesterday, and Carson Dyle. But something went wrong and they were unable to locate their contact. It must have been at that point that they decided to steal the money.

dialogue.raw_text: Carson was dying so they were forced to leave him. They finally got back to the base, made their report, and waited for the war to end. Only Charles couldn't wait quite as long as the others. He beat them back to the gold, took everything for himself and disappeared. It's taken Gideon, Tex and Scobie all this time to catch up with him again.

direction.raw_text: (PLACE ST. ANDRE DES ARTS) -- LATE AFTERNOON DYLE leaves the hotel and turns into the Place. A moment later, REGGIE comes cautiously from the hotel. As she watches DYLE, a SANDWICH-MAN advertising a driving school passes the hotel. REGGIE falls in behind him, his tall placard hiding her from view.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ANDRE DES ARTS -- LATE AFTERNOON First comes DYLE, passing a sidewalk cafe on the corner, then the SANDWICH-MAN and REGGIE. The SANDWICH-MAN turns off, leaving REGGIE out in the open. A moment later, DYLE passes a GIRL painting a canvas, her easel set up in the middle of the sidewalk. He stops when he has passed her and turns to look at her work. REGGIE, not knowing what to do, and afraid she will be seen by DYLE, who is now looking her way, spins and sits at the sidewalk cafe's nearest table, her back to DYLE. It is already occupied by a middle-aged TOURIST.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- REGGIE AND TOURIST The TOURIST, complete with camera, beret and guide book, looks up from his coffee, surprised. He stares at REGGIE and she stares back. Finally, not knowing what else to do, she smiles, then takes a portion of his brioche and eats it. He smiles back emptily, not knowing what to make of her.

As he opens his mouth to make a sound, REGGIE, her eyes on DYLE, rises quickly from the table and goes, leaving a very confused TOURIST with his mouth open. He blinks, then leaves some money on the table and starts after her.
